Students' Votes Split
In Presidential Race
College Press Service—Defying
pollsters but rewarding the ambitious student registration
drives of the last six months, an
unusally high number of
students voted on November
6th, and a surprising number of
them apparently voted for
Walter Mondale.
Though measuring the student vote is difficult, some
observers believe 40 to 50 percent of the college students
eligible to vote actually cast
ballots, and that they split them
about evenly between Mondale
and Ronald Reagan, who, of
course, won a massive victory
among the general population.
"My impression is that Mondale ran considerably better
than
expected
among
students," says Patty Cale of
the United Students of Iowa,
the statewide student group.
Cale says early returns show
"the counties where the state
universities are went heavily for
Mondale."
In the 30 campus precincts
surveyed by the Massachusetts
Public Interest Research
Group, Mondale won by a
three-to-one margin, reports
Jim Kessler of the University of
Massachusetts at Amherst.
Mondale took 65 percent of
the vote in the precincts sur-

rounding Temple University in
Philadelphia, 51 percent of the
votes around the University of
Oregon, nearly 60 percent of
the Michigan State vote, about
50 percent of the University of
Alabama vote, and little more
than half of the Ohio State student vote.
Reagan won 69 percent of
the University of Texas-Austin
vote, and 55 percent of the Illinois State campus vote,
among other college victories.
"The students just didn't like
Mondale,"
says
Jack
Abramoff, head of the College
Republicans in Washington,
D.C.
"We spent a lot of time going after the young vote," notes
Tucker Eskew of the
Reagan/Bush campaign headquarters staff.
Most scientific polls before
the
election
showed
18-to-24-year-olds favoring
President Reagan by a wide
margin.
"It's hard to tell what's the student vote and what's the
18-to-24-year-old vote," says
Kathy Ozer, lobbyist for the
U.S. Student Association.
"There are many students who
are older than 24, and not all 18
year-olds are students."

WASHINGTON—
Education Secretary Terrel H.
Bell took the lead this week on
a question that's bound to raise
the anxieties of already selfconsumed college students:
Are four years sufficient time
to earn a degree in computers
and become a Renaissance man
or woman, too?
The answer, Bell suggests, is
no. Citing a new study, "Involvement in Learning: Realizing the Potential of American
Higher Education", he says
that a fifth year may be needed
in certain undergraduate programs to arrest the "increasingly early encroachment of professionalism into liberal arts."
While such a move might mean
additional burdens on student
finances, he adds,"We need to
have broadly educated men and
women" if the United States is
to maintain its standing in the
world.
But extra semesters offer no
assurances that they'll be wellspent. As Bell well knows, it's
quality — not quantity — that
counts. Students are already
confused about the value of
liberal arts; if the five-year plan
is to receive official sanction,
educators will need to clarify
the ambiguities.
Undergraduate America's
gradual abandonment of the
humanities is an open sore. As
"Involvement in Learning"
points out, the share of
bachelor's degrees awarded in
professional or vocational programs rose from about half to
almost two-thirds between 1971
and 1982. Freshmen aren't even
going for the life sciences as
they used to; not coincidentally, degrees in business administration and engineering
enjoy a healthy demand.
Computer science and electrical engineering, for example,
are so hot at the Massachusetts

Institute of Technology that the
school may have to trim enrollment in both programs. OneM.I.T.'s

—
geography,

needed than ever. According to

scores in 11 of 15 categories of
the Graduate Record Examinations declined between 1964

Every professor has his or

freshman class couldn't locate
El Salvador. Fewer than half of
his students even knew where
Atlanta was; many confused
Japan with New Zealand.
The seven authors of "Involvement in Learning" suggest
that two full years of liberal arts
education would help to
alleviate such ignorance. One
member of the panel, Zelda
Gamson, of the University of

Its advocates still need to explain how the extra semesters
won't simply be a windfall for
treasuries.

Mitchell's Clutch Shooting Gives Jays First Win
by Mike Silverman
Sophomore forward Steve
Mitchell's two foul shots with
only two seconds remaining in
the game catapulted the
Hopkins basketball team to a
hard-fought 50-48 win over
MIT in last week's "tournament of the brains" in St.
Louis. The victory was the
Jays' first of the season and
served as a "real confidence
builder" according to head
coach "Nap" Doherty.
The Blue Jays' seasonal
record fell to 1-4 with a 72-64
loss to Washington University
in the championship game of
the tournament last Saturday,
and a 107-97 defeat at the
hands of a tough Cabrini squad
on Tuesday.
Steve Mitchell(36 points, 24
rebounds) and junior forward
Mike Kowatch (21 points, 8 rebounds,8 steals) were named to
the all-tournament team for the
two game series played at
Washington University. Their
strong play has sparked optimism in Coach Doherty's
outlook for the rest of the
season.
"I've been extremely impressed with the play of
Kowatch and Mitchell thus
far," the Coach remarked.
"We're beginning to get

balanced scoring on offense,
and with further improvements
in our ball handling skills and
offensive rebounding, we
should be more successful over
the course of the season."
Playing four of its first five
contests on the road, being
plagued by a rash of injuries,
and suffering from inexperience, the Blue Jays have
found themselves at a distinct
disadvantage in the early going
of the season. Coach Doherty
feels that the experimental process of identifying the team's
strengths and finding the best
player combinations has led to
a squad that improves with successive games.
"We haven't played as a unit
very long, but the experience we
now have should give us an extra dimension," he noted. "The
players have really hustled and
scrapped in the last few games.
Our presses looked good
against Cabrini, and I think
we'll be a contender in the
league once we cut down on
things like turnovers and poor
free throw shooting."
Despite getting double figure
scoring from three players, the
Jays were unable to keep up
with a strong Cabrini team, as
they bowed 107-97. Cabrini
(6-1) which played in the
NCAA tournament last year,

was helped by Jim Walden,
who chipped in 30 points, and
an overwhelming total of 25
Blue Jay turnovers.
Steve Mitchell tallied a
season high 25 points and 14 rebounds, while Mike Kowatch
and captain Ken Puhala each
contributed 14 points. Hopkins' inability to box out their
opponent and poor ball handling proved to be the tell-tale
factor in the contest.
"They were much stronger
off the boards and quicker than
we were," noted Doherty. "We
didn't move the ball well at all.
We had chances to beat them,
but sloppy ball handling and
turnovers kept us out of the
game."
The Blue Jays played
Lebanon Valley last night, but
the score was unavailable at
press time. The team has the
rest of the month off, and will
suit up next for the Blue Jay
Tournament on January 4 and
5
Coach Doherty expects that
his team is over its transition
period and will begin to play up
to its potential over the next 17
games. "The Christmas break
should give us the time to heal
our injuries, and get in top
form," Doherty remarked.
"We've continually improved
and the season should turn out

to be a successful one."

points and 12.2 rebounds per
game. Mike Kowatch is second
in scoring with an 11.2 average,

and captain Ken Puhala is third
with a 9.1 average. Sophomore
guard Mike Sohr leads the team
in assists with 15. The team as
a whole is shooting .430 from
the field, but only .630 from the
foul line.

by Denise Caputo
Despite some good performances, the women's basket-ball team suffered a defeat at

of the first half, they were

hard in the second half, matching Dickinson point by point,

the high scorer for the game,
bringing home 29 out of the 52

scorer, had a rough game, converting all 3 foul shots but only 2 of 16 baskets.

that the team is looking forward to meeting Dickinson on
the court again. She predicts
that the team will remain strong
on the offense, and with work,
can improve their defense. "I
think we're going to have a
really good year," commented

junior co-captain Joan Sanford, "thanks to the
newcomers and the strength of
the oldtimers, the team has
grown in size and potential."

Goucher at Homewood. The
-nly surprising feature of the

the game under control. Good

players to strive for good
discipline on the court."

defense was really on." "It was

everyone got the chance to
score," added Bartlett.

aboard
welcome
some

Weight Room to Get
Needed Renovations
by Bill Bernstein
So who says Johns Hopkins
isn't responsive to the needs of
its students?
Athletic Director Bob Scott
announced yesterday that the
weight room in the Newton H.
White Athletic Center will be
renovated and expanded, with
work beginning immediately.
The weight room wall
bordering the men's locker
room will be torn out, and the
weight room will be expanded,
nearly doubling its size.
"When we're finished, the
weight room will be about one
and three-quarters the size it is
now," Scott said. "With new
equipment to be purchased, it
will fill out what should be a
very adequate, useful room for
our students."
Scott stressed that the expansion of the weight room is not
related to a recent letter-to-theeditor of the News-Letter, calling for such a renovation.
"We've been planning
this for the last year. It has

taken time to get this approved
and funded. It's not just in
response to 'The Weightroom
Wonder's' comments," Scott
said.
Construction, already underway, is targeted to conclude by
January 21."We planned to do
this at a time that would cause
the least interruption for the
students," the athletic director
noted.
The ceiling in the new portion of the weight room will be
a full ceiling, much higher
than the existing one. This will
provide more air circulation
and better ventillation. Also,
the room will be completely
retiled. As a result of the expansion, the men's locker room
will lose three banks of lockers.
"We just have to do more
for our students in the area of
our weight room," Scott said.
"We're going to have a much
better facility. Everyone's very
excited and we all feel very good
about the improvements that
will be forthcoming."

WASHINGTON—
Education Secretary Terrel H.
Bell took the lead this week on
a question that's bound to raise
the anxieties of already selfconsumed college students:
Are four years sufficient time
to earn a degree in computers
and become a Renaissance man
or woman, too?
The answer, Bell suggests, is
no. Citing a new study, "Involvement in Learning: Realizing the Potential of American
Higher Education", he says
that a fifth year may be needed
in certain undergraduate programs to arrest the "increasingly early encroachment of professionalism into liberal arts."
While such a move might mean
additional burdens on student
finances, he adds,"We need to
have broadly educated men and
women" if the United States is
to maintain its standing in the
world.
But extra semesters offer no
assurances that they'll be wellspent. As Bell well knows, it's
quality — not quantity — that
counts. Students are already
confused about the value of
liberal arts; if the five-year plan
is to receive official sanction,
educators will need to clarify
the ambiguities.
Undergraduate America's
gradual abandonment of the
humanities is an open sore. As
"Involvement in Learning"
points out, the share of
bachelor's degrees awarded in
professional or vocational programs rose from about half to
almost two-thirds between 1971
and 1982. Freshmen aren't even
going for the life sciences as
they used to; not coincidentally, degrees in business administration and engineering
enjoy a healthy demand.

Every professor has his or

of the more astounding comes
from a geography prof at
California State University at
Fullerton, who recently found
that three-fourths of his
freshman class couldn't locate
El Salvador. Fewer than half of
his students even knew where
Atlanta was; many confused
Japan with New Zealand.
The seven authors of "Involvement in Learning" suggest
that two full years of liberal arts
education would help to
alleviate such ignorance. One
member of the panel, Zelda
Gamson, of the University of
Michigan, adds another incentive: Since, on the average, people change jobs at least five
times before their 40th birthday, "liberal arts provide
(them) with a range of skills

Some students would hardly
notice the shift. Several
schools, in fact (among them

since the 1950's, according to
President Mark Curtis of the
American Association of

days, the writers and readers

With some exceptions, tips

But there is some economic

AT&T's case, duplicated at

pitch for the five-year degree.
Its advocates still need to explain how the extra semesters
won't simply be a windfall for
treasuries.
